content: 1 The Song of Songs, by Solomon.
content_old: 1 The Song of Songs, by Solomon.

content: 2 Oh, give me of the kisses of your mouth, For your love is more delightful than wine.
content_old: 2 Oh, give me of the kisses of your mouth, For your love is more delightful than wine.

content: 3 Your ointments yield a sweet fragrance, Your name is like finest oil— Therefore do maidens love you.
content_old: 3 Your ointments yield a sweet fragrance, Your name is like finest oil— Therefore do maidens love you.

content: 4 Draw me after you, let us run! The king has brought me to his chambers. Let us delight and rejoice in your love, Savoring it more than wine— Like new wine they love you!
content_old: 4 Draw me after you, let us run! The king has brought me to his chambers. Let us delight and rejoice in your love, Savoring it more than wine— Like new wine they love you!

content: 5 I am dark, but comely, O daughters of Jerusalem— Like the tents of Kedar, Like the pavilions of Solomon.
content_old: 5 I am dark, but comely, O daughters of Jerusalem— Like the tents of Kedar, Like the pavilions of Solomon.

content: 6 Don’t stare at me because I am swarthy, Because the sun has gazed upon me. My mother’s sons quarreled with me, They made me guard the vineyards; My own vineyard I did not guard.
content_old: 6 Don’t stare at me because I am swarthy, Because the sun has gazed upon me. My mother’s sons quarreled with me, They made me guard the vineyards; My own vineyard I did not guard.

content: 7 Tell me, you whom I love so well; Where do you pasture your sheep? Where do you rest them at noon? Let me not be as one who strays Beside the flocks of your fellows.
content_old: 7 Tell me, you whom I love so well; Where do you pasture your sheep? Where do you rest them at noon? Let me not be as one who strays Beside the flocks of your fellows.

content: 8 If you do not know, O fairest of women, Go follow the tracks of the sheep, And graze your kids By the tents of the shepherds.
content_old: 8 If you do not know, O fairest of women, Go follow the tracks of the sheep, And graze your kids By the tents of the shepherds.

content: 9 I have likened you, my darling, To a mare in Pharaoh’s chariots:
content_old: 9 I have likened you, my darling, To a mare in Pharaoh’s chariots:

content: 10 Your cheeks are comely with plaited wreaths, Your neck with strings of jewels.
content_old: 10 Your cheeks are comely with plaited wreaths, Your neck with strings of jewels.

content: 11 We will add wreaths of gold To your spangles of silver.
content_old: 11 We will add wreaths of gold To your spangles of silver.

content: 12 While the king was on his couch, My nard gave forth its fragrance.
content_old: 12 While the king was on his couch, My nard gave forth its fragrance.

content: 13 My beloved to me is a bag of myrrh Lodged between my breasts.
content_old: 13 My beloved to me is a bag of myrrh Lodged between my breasts.

content: 14 My beloved to me is a spray of henna blooms From the vineyards of En-gedi.
content_old: 14 My beloved to me is a spray of henna blooms From the vineyards of En-gedi.

content: 15 Ah, you are fair, my darling, Ah, you are fair, With your dove-like eyes!
content_old: 15 Ah, you are fair, my darling, Ah, you are fair, With your dove-like eyes!

content: 16 And you, my beloved, are handsome, Beautiful indeed! Our couch is in a bower;
content_old: 16 And you, my beloved, are handsome, Beautiful indeed! Our couch is in a bower;

content: 1 I am a rose of Sharon, A lily of the valleys.
content_old: 1 I am a rose of Sharon, A lily of the valleys.

content: 2 Like a lily among thorns, So is my darling among the maidens.
content_old: 2 Like a lily among thorns, So is my darling among the maidens.

content: 3 Like an apple tree among trees of the forest, So is my beloved among the youths. I delight to sit in his shade, And his fruit is sweet to my mouth.
content_old: 3 Like an apple tree among trees of the forest, So is my beloved among the youths. I delight to sit in his shade, And his fruit is sweet to my mouth.

content: 4 He brought me to the banquet room And his banner of love was over me.
content_old: 4 He brought me to the banquet room And his banner of love was over me.

content: 5 “Sustain me with raisin cakes, Refresh me with apples, For I am faint with love.”
content_old: 5 “Sustain me with raisin cakes, Refresh me with apples, For I am faint with love.”

content: 6 His left hand was under my head, His right arm embraced me.
content_old: 6 His left hand was under my head, His right arm embraced me.

content: 7 I adjure you, O maidens of Jerusalem, By gazelles or by hinds of the field: Do not wake or rouse Love until it please!
content_old: 7 I adjure you, O maidens of Jerusalem, By gazelles or by hinds of the field: Do not wake or rouse Love until it please!

content: 8 Hark! My beloved! There he comes, Leaping over mountains, Bounding over hills.
content_old: 8 Hark! My beloved! There he comes, Leaping over mountains, Bounding over hills.

content: 9 My beloved is like a gazelle Or like a young stag. There he stands behind our wall, Gazing through the window, Peering through the lattice.
content_old: 9 My beloved is like a gazelle Or like a young stag. There he stands behind our wall, Gazing through the window, Peering through the lattice.

content: 10 My beloved spoke thus to me, “Arise, my darling; My fair one, come away!
content_old: 10 My beloved spoke thus to me, “Arise, my darling; My fair one, come away!

content: 11 For now the winter is past, The rains are over and gone.
content_old: 11 For now the winter is past, The rains are over and gone.

content: 12 The blossoms have appeared in the land, The time of pruning has come; The song of the turtledove Is heard in our land.
content_old: 12 The blossoms have appeared in the land, The time of pruning has come; The song of the turtledove Is heard in our land.

content: 13 The green figs form on the fig tree, The vines in blossom give off fragrance. Arise, my darling; My fair one, come away!
content_old: 13 The green figs form on the fig tree, The vines in blossom give off fragrance. Arise, my darling; My fair one, come away!

content: 14 “O my dove, in the cranny of the rocks, Hidden by the cliff, Let me see your face, Let me hear your voice; For your voice is sweet And your face is comely.”
content_old: 14 “O my dove, in the cranny of the rocks, Hidden by the cliff, Let me see your face, Let me hear your voice; For your voice is sweet And your face is comely.”

content: 15 Catch us the foxes, The little foxes That ruin the vineyards— For our vineyard is in blossom.
content_old: 15 Catch us the foxes, The little foxes That ruin the vineyards— For our vineyard is in blossom.

content: 16 My beloved is mine And I am his Who browses among the lilies.
content_old: 16 My beloved is mine And I am his Who browses among the lilies.

content: 1 Upon my couch at night I sought the one I love— I sought, but found him not.
content_old: 1 Upon my couch at night I sought the one I love— I sought, but found him not.

content: 2 “I must rise and roam the town, Through the streets and through the squares; I must seek the one I love.” I sought but found him not.
content_old: 2 “I must rise and roam the town, Through the streets and through the squares; I must seek the one I love.” I sought but found him not.

content: 3 I met the watchmen Who patrol the town. “Have you seen the one I love?”
content_old: 3 I met the watchmen Who patrol the town. “Have you seen the one I love?”

content: 4 Scarcely had I passed them When I found the one I love. I held him fast, I would not let him go Till I brought him to my mother’s house, To the chamber of her who conceived me
content_old: 4 Scarcely had I passed them When I found the one I love. I held him fast, I would not let him go Till I brought him to my mother’s house, To the chamber of her who conceived me

content: 5 I adjure you, O maidens of Jerusalem, By gazelles or by hinds of the field: Do not wake or rouse Love until it please!
content_old: 5 I adjure you, O maidens of Jerusalem, By gazelles or by hinds of the field: Do not wake or rouse Love until it please!

content: 6 Who is she that comes up from the desert Like columns of smoke, In clouds of myrrh and frankincense, Of all the powders of the merchant?
content_old: 6 Who is she that comes up from the desert Like columns of smoke, In clouds of myrrh and frankincense, Of all the powders of the merchant?

content: 7 There is Solomon’s couch, Encircled by sixty warriors Of the warriors of Israel,
content_old: 7 There is Solomon’s couch, Encircled by sixty warriors Of the warriors of Israel,

content: 8 All of them trained in warfare, Skilled in battle, Each with sword on thigh Because of terror by night.
content_old: 8 All of them trained in warfare, Skilled in battle, Each with sword on thigh Because of terror by night.

content: 9 King Solomon made him a palanquin Of wood from Lebanon.
content_old: 9 King Solomon made him a palanquin Of wood from Lebanon.

content: 10 He made its posts of silver, Its back of gold, Its seat of purple wool. Within, it was decked with love By the maidens of Jerusalem.
content_old: 10 He made its posts of silver, Its back of gold, Its seat of purple wool. Within, it was decked with love By the maidens of Jerusalem.

content: 1 Ah, you are fair, my darling, Ah, you are fair. Your eyes are like doves Behind your veil. Your hair is like a flock of goats Streaming down Mount Gilead.
content_old: 1 Ah, you are fair, my darling, Ah, you are fair. Your eyes are like doves Behind your veil. Your hair is like a flock of goats Streaming down Mount Gilead.

content: 2 Your teeth are like a flock of ewes Climbing up from the washing pool; All of them bear twins, And not one loses her young.
content_old: 2 Your teeth are like a flock of ewes Climbing up from the washing pool; All of them bear twins, And not one loses her young.

content: 3 Your lips are like a crimson thread, Your mouth is lovely. Your brow behind your veil like a pomegranate split open.
content_old: 3 Your lips are like a crimson thread, Your mouth is lovely. Your brow behind your veil like a pomegranate split open.

content: 4 Your neck is like the Tower of David, Built to hold weapons, Hung with a thousand shields— All the quivers of warriors.
content_old: 4 Your neck is like the Tower of David, Built to hold weapons, Hung with a thousand shields— All the quivers of warriors.

content: 5 Your breasts are like two fawns, Twins of a gazelle, Browsing among the lilies.
content_old: 5 Your breasts are like two fawns, Twins of a gazelle, Browsing among the lilies.

content: 6 When the day blows gently And the shadows flee, I will betake me to the mount of myrrh, To the hill of frankincense.
content_old: 6 When the day blows gently And the shadows flee, I will betake me to the mount of myrrh, To the hill of frankincense.

content: 7 Every part of you is fair, my darling, There is no blemish in you
content_old: 7 Every part of you is fair, my darling, There is no blemish in you

content: 8 From Lebanon come with me; From Lebanon, my bride, with me! Trip down from Amana’s peak, From the peak of Senir and Hermon, From the dens of lions, From the hills of leopards.
content_old: 8 From Lebanon come with me; From Lebanon, my bride, with me! Trip down from Amana’s peak, From the peak of Senir and Hermon, From the dens of lions, From the hills of leopards.

content: 9 You have captured my heart, My own, my bride, You have captured my heart With one glance of your eyes, With one coil of your necklace.
content_old: 9 You have captured my heart, My own, my bride, You have captured my heart With one glance of your eyes, With one coil of your necklace.

content: 10 How sweet is your love, My own, my bride! How much more delightful your love than wine, Your ointments more fragrant Than any spice!
content_old: 10 How sweet is your love, My own, my bride! How much more delightful your love than wine, Your ointments more fragrant Than any spice!

content: 11 Sweetness drops From your lips, O bride; Honey and milk Are under your tongue; And the scent of your robes Is like the scent of Lebanon.
content_old: 11 Sweetness drops From your lips, O bride; Honey and milk Are under your tongue; And the scent of your robes Is like the scent of Lebanon.

content: 12 A garden locked Is my own, my bride, A fountain locked, A sealed-up spring.
content_old: 12 A garden locked Is my own, my bride, A fountain locked, A sealed-up spring.

content: 13 Your limbs are an orchard of pomegranates And of all luscious fruits, Of henna and of nard—
content_old: 13 Your limbs are an orchard of pomegranates And of all luscious fruits, Of henna and of nard—

content: 14 Nard and saffron, Fragrant reed and cinnamon, With all aromatic woods, Myrrh and aloes— All the choice perfumes.
content_old: 14 Nard and saffron, Fragrant reed and cinnamon, With all aromatic woods, Myrrh and aloes— All the choice perfumes.

content: 15 a garden spring, A well of fresh water, A rill of Lebanon.
content_old: 15 a garden spring, A well of fresh water, A rill of Lebanon.

content: 1 I have come to my garden, My own, my bride; I have plucked my myrrh and spice, Eaten my honey and honeycomb, Drunk my wine and my milk. Eat, lovers, and drink: Drink deep of love!
content_old: 1 I have come to my garden, My own, my bride; I have plucked my myrrh and spice, Eaten my honey and honeycomb, Drunk my wine and my milk. Eat, lovers, and drink: Drink deep of love!

content: 2 I was asleep, But my heart was wakeful. Hark, my beloved knocks! “Let me in, my own, My darling, my faultless dove! For my head is drenched with dew, My locks with the damp of night.”
content_old: 2 I was asleep, But my heart was wakeful. Hark, my beloved knocks! “Let me in, my own, My darling, my faultless dove! For my head is drenched with dew, My locks with the damp of night.”

content: 3 I had taken off my robe— Was I to don it again? I had bathed my feet— Was I to soil them again?
content_old: 3 I had taken off my robe— Was I to don it again? I had bathed my feet— Was I to soil them again?

content: 4 My beloved took his hand off the latch, And my heart was stirred for him.
content_old: 4 My beloved took his hand off the latch, And my heart was stirred for him.

content: 5 I rose to let in my beloved; My hands dripped myrrh— My fingers, flowing myrrh— Upon the handles of the bolt.
content_old: 5 I rose to let in my beloved; My hands dripped myrrh— My fingers, flowing myrrh— Upon the handles of the bolt.

content: 6 I opened the door for my beloved, But my beloved had turned and gone. I was faint because of what he said. I sought, but found him not; I called, but he did not answer.
content_old: 6 I opened the door for my beloved, But my beloved had turned and gone. I was faint because of what he said. I sought, but found him not; I called, but he did not answer.

content: 7 I met the watchmen Who patrol the town; They struck me, they bruised me. The guards of the walls Stripped me of my mantle.
content_old: 7 I met the watchmen Who patrol the town; They struck me, they bruised me. The guards of the walls Stripped me of my mantle.

content: 8 I adjure you, O maidens of Jerusalem! If you meet my beloved, tell him this: That I am faint with love.
content_old: 8 I adjure you, O maidens of Jerusalem! If you meet my beloved, tell him this: That I am faint with love.

content: 9 How is your beloved better than another, O fairest of women? How is your beloved better than another That you adjure us so?
content_old: 9 How is your beloved better than another, O fairest of women? How is your beloved better than another That you adjure us so?

content: 10 My beloved is clear-skinned and ruddy, Preeminent among ten thousand.
content_old: 10 My beloved is clear-skinned and ruddy, Preeminent among ten thousand.

content: 11 His head is finest gold, His locks are curled And black as a raven.
content_old: 11 His head is finest gold, His locks are curled And black as a raven.

content: 12 His eyes are like doves By watercourses, Bathed in milk, Set by a brimming pool.
content_old: 12 His eyes are like doves By watercourses, Bathed in milk, Set by a brimming pool.

content: 13 His cheeks are like beds of spices, Banks of perfume His lips are like lilies; They drip flowing myrrh.
content_old: 13 His cheeks are like beds of spices, Banks of perfume His lips are like lilies; They drip flowing myrrh.

content: 14 His hands are rods of gold, Studded with beryl; His belly a tablet of ivory, Adorned with sapphires.
content_old: 14 His hands are rods of gold, Studded with beryl; His belly a tablet of ivory, Adorned with sapphires.

content: 15 His legs are like marble pillars Set in sockets of fine gold. He is majestic as Lebanon, Stately as the cedars.
content_old: 15 His legs are like marble pillars Set in sockets of fine gold. He is majestic as Lebanon, Stately as the cedars.

content: 1 “Whither has your beloved gone, O fairest of women? Whither has your beloved turned? Let us seek him with you.”
content_old: 1 “Whither has your beloved gone, O fairest of women? Whither has your beloved turned? Let us seek him with you.”

content: 2 My beloved has gone down to his garden, To the beds of spices, To browse in the gardens And to pick lilies.
content_old: 2 My beloved has gone down to his garden, To the beds of spices, To browse in the gardens And to pick lilies.

content: 3 I am my beloved’s And my beloved is mine; He browses among the lilies.
content_old: 3 I am my beloved’s And my beloved is mine; He browses among the lilies.

content: 4 You are beautiful, my darling, as Tirzah, Comely as Jerusalem, Awesome as bannered hosts.
content_old: 4 You are beautiful, my darling, as Tirzah, Comely as Jerusalem, Awesome as bannered hosts.

content: 5 Turn your eyes away from me, For they overwhelm me! Your hair is like a flock of goats Streaming down from Gilead.
content_old: 5 Turn your eyes away from me, For they overwhelm me! Your hair is like a flock of goats Streaming down from Gilead.

content: 6 Your teeth are like a flock of ewes Climbing up from the washing pool; All of them bear twins, And not one loses her young.
content_old: 6 Your teeth are like a flock of ewes Climbing up from the washing pool; All of them bear twins, And not one loses her young.

content: 7 Your brow behind your veil like a pomegranate split open.
content_old: 7 Your brow behind your veil like a pomegranate split open.

content: 8 There are sixty queens, And eighty concubines, And damsels without number.
content_old: 8 There are sixty queens, And eighty concubines, And damsels without number.

content: 9 Only one is my dove, My perfect one, The only one of her mother, The delight of her who bore her. Maidens see and acclaim her; Queens and concubines, and praise her.
content_old: 9 Only one is my dove, My perfect one, The only one of her mother, The delight of her who bore her. Maidens see and acclaim her; Queens and concubines, and praise her.

content: 10 Who is she that shines through like the dawn, Beautiful as the moon, Radiant as the sun Awesome as bannered hosts?
content_old: 10 Who is she that shines through like the dawn, Beautiful as the moon, Radiant as the sun Awesome as bannered hosts?

content: 11 I went down to the nut grove To see the budding of the vale; To see if the vines had blossomed, If the pomegranates were in bloom.
content_old: 11 I went down to the nut grove To see the budding of the vale; To see if the vines had blossomed, If the pomegranates were in bloom.

content: 1 Turn back, turn back, O maid of Shulem! Turn back, turn back, That we may gaze upon you. “Why will you gaze at the Shulammite In the Mahanaim dance?”
content_old: 1 Turn back, turn back, O maid of Shulem! Turn back, turn back, That we may gaze upon you. “Why will you gaze at the Shulammite In the Mahanaim dance?”

content: 2 How lovely are your feet in sandals, O daughter of nobles! Your rounded thighs are like jewels, The work of a master’s hand.
content_old: 2 How lovely are your feet in sandals, O daughter of nobles! Your rounded thighs are like jewels, The work of a master’s hand.

content: 3 Your navel is like a round goblet— Let mixed wine not be lacking!— Your belly like a heap of wheat Hedged about with lilies.
content_old: 3 Your navel is like a round goblet— Let mixed wine not be lacking!— Your belly like a heap of wheat Hedged about with lilies.

content: 4 Your breasts are like two fawns, Twins of a gazelle.
content_old: 4 Your breasts are like two fawns, Twins of a gazelle.

content: 5 Your neck is like a tower of ivory, Your eyes like pools in Heshbon By the gate of Bath-rabbim, Your nose like the Lebanon tower That faces toward Damascus.
content_old: 5 Your neck is like a tower of ivory, Your eyes like pools in Heshbon By the gate of Bath-rabbim, Your nose like the Lebanon tower That faces toward Damascus.

content: 6 The head upon you is like crimson wool, The locks of your head are like purple— A king is held captive in the tresses.
content_old: 6 The head upon you is like crimson wool, The locks of your head are like purple— A king is held captive in the tresses.

content: 7 How fair you are, how beautiful! O Love, with all its rapture!
content_old: 7 How fair you are, how beautiful! O Love, with all its rapture!

content: 8 Your stately form is like the palm, Your breasts are like clusters.
content_old: 8 Your stately form is like the palm, Your breasts are like clusters.

content: 9 I say: Let me climb the palm, Let me take hold of its branches; Let your breasts be like clusters of grapes, Your breath like the fragrance of apples,
content_old: 9 I say: Let me climb the palm, Let me take hold of its branches; Let your breasts be like clusters of grapes, Your breath like the fragrance of apples,

content: 10 And your mouth like choicest wine. “Let it flow to my beloved as new wine Gliding over the lips of sleepers.”
content_old: 10 And your mouth like choicest wine. “Let it flow to my beloved as new wine Gliding over the lips of sleepers.”

content: 11 I am my beloved’s, And his desire is for me.
content_old: 11 I am my beloved’s, And his desire is for me.

content: 12 Come, my beloved, Let us go into the open; Let us lodge among the henna shrubs.
content_old: 12 Come, my beloved, Let us go into the open; Let us lodge among the henna shrubs.

content: 13 Let us go early to the vineyards; Let us see if the vine has flowered, If its blossoms have opened, If the pomegranates are in bloom. There I will give my love to you.
content_old: 13 Let us go early to the vineyards; Let us see if the vine has flowered, If its blossoms have opened, If the pomegranates are in bloom. There I will give my love to you.

content: 1 If only it could be as with a brother, As if you had nursed at my mother’s breast: Then I could kiss you When I met you in the street, And no one would despise me.
content_old: 1 If only it could be as with a brother, As if you had nursed at my mother’s breast: Then I could kiss you When I met you in the street, And no one would despise me.

content: 2 I would lead you, I would bring you To the house of my mother, Of her who taught me— I would let you drink of the spiced wine, Of my pomegranate juice.
content_old: 2 I would lead you, I would bring you To the house of my mother, Of her who taught me— I would let you drink of the spiced wine, Of my pomegranate juice.

content: 3 His left hand was under my head, His right hand caressed me.
content_old: 3 His left hand was under my head, His right hand caressed me.

content: 4 I adjure you, O maidens of Jerusalem: Do not wake or rouse Love until it please!
content_old: 4 I adjure you, O maidens of Jerusalem: Do not wake or rouse Love until it please!

content: 5 Who is she that comes up from the desert, Leaning upon her beloved? Under the apple tree I roused you; It was there your mother conceived you, There she who bore you conceived you.
content_old: 5 Who is she that comes up from the desert, Leaning upon her beloved? Under the apple tree I roused you; It was there your mother conceived you, There she who bore you conceived you.

content: 6 Let me be a seal upon your heart, Like the seal upon your hand. For love is fierce as death, Passion is mighty as Sheol; Its darts are darts of fire, A blazing flame.
content_old: 6 Let me be a seal upon your heart, Like the seal upon your hand. For love is fierce as death, Passion is mighty as Sheol; Its darts are darts of fire, A blazing flame.

content: 7 Vast floods cannot quench love, Nor rivers drown it. If a man offered all his wealth for love, He would be laughed to scorn.
content_old: 7 Vast floods cannot quench love, Nor rivers drown it. If a man offered all his wealth for love, He would be laughed to scorn.

content: 8 “We have a little sister, Whose breasts are not yet formed. What shall we do for our sister When she is spoken for?
content_old: 8 “We have a little sister, Whose breasts are not yet formed. What shall we do for our sister When she is spoken for?

content: 9 If she be a wall, We will build upon it a silver battlement; If she be a door, We will panel it in cedar.”
content_old: 9 If she be a wall, We will build upon it a silver battlement; If she be a door, We will panel it in cedar.”

content: 10 I am a wall, My breasts are like towers. So I became in his eyes As one who finds favor.
content_old: 10 I am a wall, My breasts are like towers. So I became in his eyes As one who finds favor.

content: 11 Solomon had a vineyard In Baal-hamon. He had to post guards in the vineyard: A man would give for its fruit A thousand pieces of silver.
content_old: 11 Solomon had a vineyard In Baal-hamon. He had to post guards in the vineyard: A man would give for its fruit A thousand pieces of silver.

content: 12 I have my very own vineyard: You may have the thousand, O Solomon, And the guards of the fruit two hundred!
content_old: 12 I have my very own vineyard: You may have the thousand, O Solomon, And the guards of the fruit two hundred!

content: 13 O you who linger in the garden, A lover is listening; Let me hear your voice.
content_old: 13 O you who linger in the garden, A lover is listening; Let me hear your voice.
